normalised: Okay, so you are heading to the bazaar to grab some sabzi, eh? It is always a bit of an adventure, especially when you are trying to figure out how much to buy. Let us face it, figuring out units while negotiating for the best price can be a sport of its own.

unnormalised: First off, you'll probably be dealing with **kg** (kilograms) for the staples. Potatoes, onions, tomatoes - generally sold by the kilo. You might ask for "1 kg aloo" or "2 kg pyaaz". Simple enough, right? But then the vendor might say, "Yeh aloo toh bada achha hai, 1 kg mein 8-10 aayega". Basically, he's trying to tell you the quality is good by suggesting the number of potatoes you'll get in 1 kg. Don't let him fool you!

Basically, he is trying to tell you the quality is good by suggesting the number of potatoes you will get in one kilogram. Do not let him fool you!

unnormalised: Then comes the trickier stuff. Leafy greens like spinach (paalak) or coriander (dhaniya) are often sold in **bunches**. "Ek bunch dhaniya dena bhaiyya". But the size of the bunch can vary wildly! One vendor's bunch might be a tiny handful, while another's could be bursting with leaves. Always eyeball it and haggle if it looks too small. Sometimes they'll sell it by weight too, maybe "250 gm paalak dena". A quarter kg, makes sense!

Sometimes they will sell it by weight too, maybe "two hundred and fifty gram paalak dena". A quarter kilogram, makes sense!

unnormalised: For smaller quantities, like chilies (mirchi) or ginger (adrak), you'll often hear the vendor quoting a price per "pav" (quarter of a kilogram or 250g). "Mirchi ka bhav kya hai? Rs. 20 pav". This is pretty common in many parts of India.

unnormalised: Don't forget the liquids! Milk (doodh) is usually sold in **litres**. You might ask for "1 litre doodh" or "aadha litre" (half a litre). Oil, too, is usually sold in litres, like "2 litres tel". But be careful, some vendors might try to sell you cooking oil in **grams**, making it seem cheaper. Always check!

unnormalised: Spices (masale) are a whole different ballgame. They're often sold in **grams**, especially the expensive ones like saffron (kesar). You might ask for "10 gm kesar". But the smaller, local shops might still use older units like "tola", which is about 11.66 grams. Good luck converting that on the fly!

unnormalised: And finally, remember fruits! Some are sold by weight (**kg**), like apples or oranges. Others are sold by the **dozen** (darjan) like bananas. "Ek darjan kela dena". Of course, the size of the fruit matters. "Yeh kela bahut chota hai," you might say, if they try to pass off small bananas as a full dozen.

unnormalised: So, there you have it. Navigating the units of measurement at an Indian sabzi mandi is an art form. Keep your wits about you, practice your haggling skills, and don't be afraid to ask for clarification! And maybe carry a small notebook to jot down prices per kg, so you can compare different vendors and get the best deal. Happy shopping!
